comments.commentBody: The Washington post just broke the news that Jeff Sessions the new Attorney General met with the Russians multiple times during the campaign.  He appears to have lied to congress about it (during his confirmation hearings).  Special prosecutor anyone?

Time for that special prosecutor. Now Jeff Sessions has been tied to meetings with the Russian ambassador during the Presidential campaign.

We could see the first President in our history to be indicted for treason. Let's have at it, Congress.
Keep the pressure on.  The fourth estate shall not be silenced!

replies.commentBody: On the contrary, democrats have to prove that Sessions' contacts with the Russian ambassador were related to the election.  This isn't a witch hunt.  Democrats still have to prove their accusations.

comments.commentBody:
Jeff Sessions has to prove himself that he hadn't been colluding with Russia in an effort to influence the November election, despite evidence that he'd had contacts with the Russian ambassador. He should heed the demands of congressional Democrats and "recluse himself from overseeing any investigation into Russia’s contacts with the Trump campaign."
On February 15, Lindsey Graham said that Russia and "any Trump person who was working with the Russians in an unacceptable way also needs to pay a price.” He has to ensure that Sessions, his "dear friend" upholds the integrity of an attorney general and the principle of the rule of law.
Trump and his people have been lying all along. Why lie if there is no there there as they would have us all believe?

replies.commentBody: So you suggest the DNC corruption should have been covered up to help Hilary win?
They allegedly "hacked" the election by revealing that Clinton and the DNC colluded to undermine Sanders campaign.

@Citizen: but what you describe makes no sense. The Russians would had to figure out the intricacies of US politics -- missed by the media, NYT, Nate Silver and other respected bloggers, and all the major polling companies. Then the Russians would have had to send careful teams of infiltrators into JUST THE RIGHT counties and states, in FLYOVER country -- know that they could turn (say) Michigan but NOT Illinois -- and do so with SURGICAL precision -- and this would include putting thousand and thousands of Trump signs on lawns.

That is some pretty spiffy intelligence action, folks! and from the people who LOST THE COLD WAR!

As someone who lives in Middle America and flyover country, let me tell you that Comey's "revelations" meant zero to us. I had already voted by absentee ballot. They could have found either candidate having sex with a goat on the peak of the Washington monument by that late in the election and it would not have changed anyone's vote.

If Trump and "the Russkies" colluded...my lord, they sure choose an unorthodox way of doing so! did the Russians tell Trump to mock a disabled reporter, knowing that was a "sure path to victory"? Hope about those "groping tapes" -- did the Russians release those, knowing they would catapult Trump to victory? or tell him "go mock a Gold Star family; the voters will LOVE that"?

Come on! Trump ran one of the craziest, most hare-brained campaigns in US History! NOBODY could have designed it that way.

comments.commentBody: Exactly how were state election systems tampered with?  Does this mean that Russians hacked voting machines?  I am genuinely confused

What exactly does the nytimes think the Russians did? Hold secret cloak and dagger meetings...with Russians...to discuss what exactly?

This is manufactured smoke looking for a crime. I say "manufactured" because with nary a named source it finds itself yet again on the front page in breathless paragraphs.

Yet perhaps the left will find a sought-after crime to get a clean hit on Trump- a la Scooter Libby in the Plame affair. This all smells like a political take down attempt to me.

Let's wait for the house Intel report, until then I'd appreciate if the nytimes took the panic down a couple notches. Trump is our legitimate president. Get over it.

replies.commentBody: Please have more faith in our media -- the mainstream media, that is, and in quiet, devoted American patriots.  Why do you think Trump is working so hard to demean and marginalize journalists who dare write critically about him?

Anne-Marie --- The denial is a result of the Clinton credibility on the Dems side.  (It makes me mad Obama gets the short end because of it.)  People don't know who to believe, given one got caught saying "I did not.....", when in fact, he did.

comments.commentBody:
I have little hope that any of this will go anywhere. It seems that we are in an era when denial with confidence and repeatedly changes what the truth is. Trump and his cabal simply assert their alternative facts while stubbornly refusing to cooperate or turn over information.

Trump & Co have successfully made the media the anti-Christ to their savior, so that a large portion of the population refuses to believe anything which comes from the media or fact-checkers. They have found that lies asserted often enough and with extreme confidence become "the truth."

We are stuck with their reality, my friends, and any shadowy dealings they chose to have until Jan 2021.

replies.commentBody:
Rosa:

Excellent! Failed Yemen raid is Trump's Trumpgazi!

comments.commentBody:
Trumpgazi.
Lock him up.

Thank you for keeping your focus on this most important of stories. There have been so many distractions---I was about to say "since the election," but really, since Trump announced his candidacy---but they shouldn't displace the attention the world should be paying to this dangerous piece of espionage.
This is looking worse with every day that passes. The United States needs to get to the bottom of it and let the chips fall where they may.

replies.commentBody: You make it sound like Mrs. Owens were used somehow.  Please don't impose sexist stereotypes, that she was somehow the little woman and is being manipulated in her mourning.  Would you make the same presumption for a male spouse, were Specialist Owens gay?

comments.commentBody:
Trumpgate 1, Vladgate 1.

Whatever the ultimate outcome, Nixon's Watergate will be dwarfed by them, as the Trumps' currently opaque deals start to leak and become transparent.

It's sad and unethical that our President is demeaning the US and us, due to his refusal to be transparent, and his own selfishness to exploit the Office of the Presidency for his own private businesses, for his own self-aggrandizement.

A decent human being would set an opposite example. He doesn't have the inner strength and moral fortitude to do the right thing, and instead promoting and participating in flooding his own swamp, which he promised to drain.

He doesn't have the moral capability to put the US first before himself. He must always win and come first. When he gets to the pearly gates, there will only be a down escalator for him to stoke the furnaces for the rest of us.

Bill Owens, the father of fallen seal Ryan Owens refused to meet Trump. Yet Trump disrespected Bill Owens, and had the audacity to parade Ryan Owen's wife as a spectacle in front of the whole country on television while grieving her very recent loss. His statement about the applause, was disrespectful and demeaning. This manifests that Trump knows no boundaries of decency.
Thank you President Obama! Hopefully, the whole, messy truth will come out soon.

If President Obama had done as many commenters feel he should have and taken a more "decisive" or "aggressive" action, all that would have happened is that the entire thing would have been dismissed out of hand as nothing more than partisan "sore looser" ness and the investigation would have come to a screeching halt. As cordial and accommodating as Mr Obama might be in public, he's certainly not an idiot and knows precisely who he is dealing with in either Trump himself or any of his minions.

No, Mr Obama did exactly the right thing under the circumstances - those being having been obstructed throughout his presidency by GOP bigwigs like McConnell et al; and having his party's candidate not win the Electoral College to the tune of some pretty terrifying rhetoric. To make open accusations would have been fruitless and potentially more dangerous.

I now think there was a great deal more to what he said in his final press briefing, and in the message he gave then: "It goes without saying that essential to [Democracy] is a free press. That is part of how this place, this country, this grand experiment of self-government has to work... You are the conduit through which [the people] receive the information about what's taking place in the halls of power. So America needs you and our democracy needs you... And my hope is that you will continue... to do the hard work of getting to the bottom of stories..."

Please keep doing so, NYT. Your country needs you.

replies.commentBody: Trump loves to accuse others of actions he has done himself but at some point his lies will come crashing down on him.

comments.commentBody:
The irony is not lost on me - Trumpy complained all along that it was a "rigged election" while he and his minions were busy rigging it with the assistance of the Russian government.
.
As it turns out that blabber mouth TOLD us what he was doing. And millions bought his treasonous lies and became unwitting aids in his collusion.

replies.commentBody: The question and answer had to do with contacts by President Trump's campaign. The times only selectively quotes the answer, and does not quote the question at all, so you are buying fake news.

Sessions came into contact with alot of Ambassadors including the Russian Ambassador during functions in his regular duties as Senator. There is nothing indicating that he had any private meetings. Gads if this was a Democratic Senator/AG that little fact would lead the headline and you'd be saying the Republicans were picking Fly
specks out of the pepper.

"What to do with Traitorous Trump?"

18 U.S. Code § 2381 states:
Whoever, owing allegiance to the United States, levies war against them or adheres to their enemies, giving them aid and comfort within the United States or elsewhere, is guilty of treason and shall suffer death, or shall be imprisoned not less than five years and fined under this title but not less than $10,000; and shall be incapable of holding any office under the United States.

The full extent of the penal law should apply to Trump.

comments.commentBody:
It seems that Jeff Sessions committed perjury during his confirmation hearing vis à vis Attorney General.

The Washington Post reports that Sessions spoke twice during the Trump campaign. MSNBC played a video clip from the hearing in which Sessions said he had not talked with Russia. Perjury.

Sessions should resign.

What to do with Traitorous Trump?
This is like a movie that will feel long and boring but you can't leave the theater because you know the ending will be spectacular.

replies.commentBody: And the FACT that Clinton was caught lying to Congress? Nothing?

comments.commentBody:
In addition to the question of whether Sessions committed perjury during his confirmation hearing and the involvement of Sessions or Trump and others in colluding with Russia to influence the election I am also concerned about:

Sessions' position and lack of action in current lawsuits about voter ID.

Sessions' statement that he will no longer monitor abuses in police departments.

Coretta Scott King's letter that Senator Elizabeth Warren was prevented from reading should have been heeded.;

replies.commentBody: Funny. None of you said that about the server.
reminds me so much of Watergate, the facts coming out piecemeal.  I want Trump to wear orange, the sooner the better. he's a traitor.
Or at least it warrants an investigation...

comments.commentBody: If it looks like a smoking gun, feels like a smoking gun, and smells like a smoking gun, then it's probably a smoking gun...

DJT could achieve clarity by releasing his tax returns and be transparent.  ASAP please sir.  Prove your patriotism to America.  While your gyrations have held the world's attention and some may believe you are "entertaining" it is time to quit playing the role of POTUS and actually behave as POTUS.  If you have done nothing wrong then why hide this information that would demonstrate this?  To Congress: please pass laws requiring future POTUS to release their tax returns, financial information and conflicts of interest.

replies.commentBody: In your dreams.
And , what are they ?

It is not enough that Trump must be removed from office.  Pence, like the guy who is ostensibly nothing more than the piano player in a raided bordello, is a willing collaborator in everything the Trump team has done -- both before the election and after the election.  Then there is Paul Ryan, number three in the line of succession should Trump and Pence each be given new quarters in the federal guest house at Florence, Colorado.
replies.userLocation: Way Out West between Broadway and Philadelphia

comments.commentBody:
Trump must quit.
During a TV interview, a few days before the election, Rudee Jouleeyawnee said "we have a few tricks up our sleeves" This was repeated by other campaign people.
Now we are finding out what those tricks were.
He's gotta go.

replies.commentBody: Exactly. Brain over brawn. Game OVER!

I really wish I could confidently agree with you. With impeachment power in Congress, I am not sure that the Republicans are willing to protect the process and the office. The ultimate findings will have to be unequivocal, not subject to interpretation, and egregious.

comments.commentBody: Trump and his administration are too stupid to survive the trail left by the Obama.  Only a matter of time.

The Obama administration sent political operatives from Obama's campaign to Israel to try and enable the defeat of Bibi Netanyahu.  And this was done with US taxpayer money.  It's very entertaining the way these same loyalists become so self-righteous when other nations may have attempted to influence our own election.

replies.commentBody: Gulag
Тюрьма (sounds  tyurma). Still with T.

comments.commentBody: Hey Donald: how do you say prison? In Russian?    So sad.

replies.commentBody: No, they know how to corrupt.  There's a huge difference.

Agreed! While I am quite critical of the Democrats' corporate ties and militarism, they at least have

upheld basic constitutional principles,

agree with the rule of law,

care about the least among us,

support democracy,

wish to expand the franchise not deny it,

respect facts and the freedom of the press,

believe in science,

understand that global warming is real and manmade,

etc.

They also have been aware of the threat Russia and Putin play on the world stage.

comments.commentBody: Backing up to get a long sight-line on this frightening situation one thing shines out: the Democrats have their problems, but they understand how to govern in ways the republicans have not grasped for many many years.
